title: A Randomized, Double-Blind, Placebo-Controlled Trial of Valproate to Attenuate the Progression of Alzheimer's Disease (AD)
description_brief: The purpose of this trial is to demonstrate whether valproate therapy delays the emergence of agitation and/or psychosis in outpatients with probable Alzheimer's disease (AD) who have not experienced agitation and psychosis in their illness. A secondary aim is to determine whether valproate therapy delays the progression of cognitive and functional measures of the illness. This trial will also assess the tolerability and safety of low-dose, long-term valproate therapy. Valproate, an anticonvulsant drug, was selected because of its possible symptomatic efficacy for agitation in AD, known safety profile in numerous clinical populations, and in view of recent data supporting its neuroprotective potential in AD.
description_detailed:
This study represents a novel clinical trial strategy designed to assess both prospective "prophylactic" therapy for psychopathology in Alzheimer's disease (AD) and to assess an approach that may alter several aspects of the pathophysiology of AD, and perhaps result in alteration of clinical progression of illness. Interpretation of these results will be supported by study of relevant biomarkers and imaging data. Valproate was selected because of its possible symptomatic efficacy for agitation in AD, known safety profile in numerous clinical populations, and in view of recent data supporting its neuroprotective potential in AD. The primary hypothesis is that chronic valproate administration to participants with AD who lack agitation and psychosis at baseline will delay the emergence of agitation and/or psychosis. An effect of this nature may have significant public health implications, for instance, by delaying institutionalization.

This is a randomized, placebo-controlled, double blind, multicenter 26-month trial of valproate therapy at a target dose of 10-12 mg/kg/day in 300 outpatients with mild to moderate Alzheimer's Disease (AD) who lack agitation and psychosis at baseline and since onset of illness. Participants will have regular clinic visits as well as telephone contacts for assessment of behavior, cognition, function, safety and tolerability. The chief secondary aim is to determine whether valproate administration to participants with AD will attenuate clinical progression of illness measured by a reduced rate of cognitive or functional decline. In addition, issues related to safety and tolerability with low-dose (10-12 mg/kg/day) therapy will be addressed. Biological specimens will be obtained to study markers selected for their relevance to the disease as well as the postulated mechanism of action of the valproate therapy. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scans will be performed prior to experimental treatment and after one year in a subset of participants in order to address possible drug-placebo differences in brain volume measures.

Approximately 300 participants from 25-35 clinical trial centers in the United States will be enrolled. Participation will include men and women with a diagnosis of probable Alzheimer's disease, age 55 or older, weighing at least 40 kg (88.2 lbs.), residing in the community at baseline, Mini Mental State Examination (MMSE) 10-20 inclusive, who have not experienced agitation or psychosis since the onset of their illness and who do not require treatment with psychotropic medications with the exception of antidepressants used only for treatment of depressive symptoms and limited use of sedatives for sleep. Participants, their relatives, guardians or authorized representatives and informants will be given ample opportunity to inquire about details of the study. Informed consent forms covering consent for the trial itself as well as the genetic research and biological sample storage and MRI scans will be provided to protect the patient's rights and confidentiality.

groups.title: Valproate
groups.description: 250mg tablets beginning with one daily for one week, then two daily for one week, then titrated according to body weight and tolerability to achieve 10-12 mg/kg daily for 2 years, followed by a 2-month washout

groups.title: Placebo
groups.description: Placebo tablets beginning with one daily and increasing according to weight and perceived tolerability concerns for two years, followed by a 2-month washout

groups.title: Valproate
groups.description: 250mg tablets beginning with one daily for one week, then two daily for one week, then titrated according to body weight and tolerability to achieve 10-12 mg/kg daily for 2 years, followed by a 2-month washout

groups.title: Placebo
groups.description: Placebo tablets beginning with one daily and increasing according to weight and perceived tolerability concerns for two years, followed by a 2-month washout

measures.title: ADAScog
measures.description: Alzheimer's Disease Assessment Scale, cognitive sub-scale in points per year (ADAS-cog) is a psychometric measure sensitive to change in mild to moderate AD. The range of this instrument is 0 to 70 with higher numbers indicating greater impairment.

measures.title: ADCS-ADL
measures.description: Alzheimer's Disease Cooperative Study Activities of Daily Living Score (ADCS-ADL) is a structured questionnaire about activities of daily living, administered to the subject's caregiver/study partner. The range of this instrument is 0 to 78 with lower numbers indicating greater impairment.

measures.title: CDR-SOB
measures.description: Clinical Dementia Rating, Sum of Boxes (CDR-SOB) is a global rating of dementia severity based on the clinician's interpretation of the history and examination. The range of this instrument is 0 to 18 with higher numbers indicating greater impairment.

measures.title: CMAI
measures.description: The Cohen-Mansfield Agitation Inventory (CMAI) is a 29-item caregiver rating questionnaire for the assessment of agitation in older persons. It includes descriptions of 29 agitated behaviors, each rated on a 7-point scale of frequency. The range of this instrument is 29 to 203 with higher numbers indicating greater impairment.

measures.title: NPI
measures.description: The Neuropsychiatric Inventory (NPI) quantifies behavioral changes in dementia, including depression, anxiety, psychosis, agitation, sleep change, appetite change, and others. This is a structured questionnaire administered to the subject's caregiver/study partner. The range of this instrument is 0 to 120 with higher numbers indicating greater impairment.

outcomeMeasures.title: Presence of Agitation and/or Psychosis Measured by the Neuropsychiatric Inventory (NPI) Combined With an Assessment of the Clinical Significance of Behavioral Change Rated by the Study Clinician
outcomeMeasures.description: NPI quantifies behavioral changes in dementia, including depression, anxiety, psychosis, agitation, and others. This is a questionnaire administered to the subject's study partner. The range of this instrument is 0 to 120 with higher numbers indicating greater impairment. To determine whether or not psychosis or agitation is present, there is no cutoff score but is based on the clinician's judgment. In the NPI, the subject responds to 'Yes' or 'No' questions. Then it is determined how often psychosis or agitation occurs and if it is mild, moderate or severe.

outcomeMeasures.description: The Cohen-Mansfield Agitation Inventory (CMAI) is a 29-item caregiver rating questionnaire for the assessment of agitation in older persons. It includes descriptions of 29 agitated behaviors, each rated on a 7-point scale of frequency. The range of this instrument is 29 to 203 with higher numbers indicating greater impairment.

outcomeMeasures.title: Participant's Clinical Condition or Endpoint Assessed With the ADCS-Clinical Global Impression of Change (ADCS-CGIC)
outcomeMeasures.description: ADCS-Clinical Global Impression of Change (ADCS-CGIC) provides a means to reliably assess global change from baseline. It provides a semi-structured format to allow clinicians to gather necessary clinical information from both the participant and informant, in order to make an overall impression of clinical change. The range of this instrument is 1 to 7 with lower numbers indicating improvement and higher numbers indicating a worsened state.

explanation_target: Reason: The trial's stated primary purpose is to determine whether valproate delays the emergence of agitation and/or psychosis in outpatients with probable Alzheimer's disease — i.e., prevention of neuropsychiatric symptoms. Although a secondary aim is to assess effects on cognitive/functional progression and there is mention of possible neuroprotective potential, the primary intent (prophylaxis of agitation/psychosis) is symptom-directed rather than a pathology-targeted disease‑modifying biologic approach. (Category definitions: Disease‑targeted biologic = biologics aimed at AD pathology; Disease‑targeted small molecule = small molecules aimed at AD pathology; Cognitive enhancer = drugs intended to improve cognition without targeting pathology; Neuropsychiatric symptom improvement = interventions to prevent/treat behavioral or psychiatric symptoms.)

Act: Key extracted details: drug = valproate (an anticonvulsant/mood stabilizer, small molecule; also exists as divalproex sodium), trial design = randomized, double‑blind, placebo‑controlled, multicenter, 24–26 month prophylactic study enrolling outpatients with mild–moderate AD who lacked agitation/psychosis at baseline; primary outcome = time to emergence of clinically significant agitation or psychosis; secondary outcomes = cognitive and functional decline; safety/tolerability assessed. Evidence from trial registry and ADCS description supports these design elements. citeturn0search8turn0search4

Web evidence about the drug and trial (selected results): (1) The ADCS/NIH trial description and protocol confirm the primary objective to delay emergence of agitation/psychosis and the secondary aim to assess clinical progression; valproate was chosen for possible symptomatic efficacy for agitation and for preclinical data suggesting neuroprotective potential. citeturn0search4turn0search2 (2) The published multicenter randomized placebo‑controlled trial (ADCS valproate neuroprotection trial) found that valproate did not delay emergence of agitation/psychosis or slow cognitive/functional decline and was associated with higher rates of adverse effects and greater brain volume loss on MRI. This supports interpretation that the tested intervention was intended for neuropsychiatric symptom prevention but failed to show benefit. citeturn0search0 (3) Earlier and shorter randomized trials and reviews examined valproate/divalproex for agitation in dementia with mixed or negative results and tolerability concerns. citeturn0search11turn0search1turn0search6 (4) Valproate (valproic acid/divalproex) is a small‑molecule anticonvulsant/mood stabilizer with multiple mechanisms (GABAergic effects and histone deacetylase inhibition among others), which explains rationale for proposed neuroprotective properties in preclinical studies. citeturn1search0turn1search7

Reflect: Classification check — valproate is a small molecule but in this trial it is being tested primarily to prevent neuropsychiatric symptoms (agitation/psychosis). That maps best to the 'neuropsychiatric symptom improvement' category (prophylaxis/treatment of behavioral symptoms). Although the protocol mentions neuroprotective potential and cognitive/functional outcomes as secondary aims, those are secondary and the primary outcome targets neuropsychiatric symptom prevention; therefore the correct category is 'neuropsychiatric symptom improvement'. The web sources cited above (trial registry/ADCS description and the published trial) corroborate the extracted aims and outcomes. citeturn0search8turn0search4turn0search0
explanation_agent: Reason: The intervention is valproate/divalproex, a small‑molecule anticonvulsant/mood stabilizer with multiple pharmacologic actions (GABAergic modulation, voltage‑gated sodium channel effects, and histone deacetylase (HDAC) inhibition/epigenetic effects). The trial’s primary intent was prophylaxis of neuropsychiatric symptoms (agitation/psychosis) in AD rather than selective engagement of a single AD molecular pathology; mechanistically the drug does not map to one singular CADRO target class. citeturn0search4turn0search5

Act: Key extracted details and mapping: drug = valproate/divalproex (small molecule) tested in a randomized, double‑blind, placebo‑controlled ADCS trial whose primary objective was to delay emergence of agitation/psychosis; secondary aims included cognition/functional progression and biomarker/imaging assessments. Because valproate acts via multiple distinct mechanisms (neurotransmitter modulation, ion channel effects, and epigenetic HDAC inhibition), the most specific CADRO assignment is R) Multi-target rather than a single-category assignment (e.g., D or Q). citeturn0search0turn0search8

Reflect: This classification aligns with the trial description and CADRO definitions — although the trial was symptom‑directed (neuropsychiatric symptom improvement), CADRO categories are organized by biological targets. Valproate’s diverse mechanisms span neurotransmitter/ion‑channel actions and epigenetic regulation; when an intervention clearly engages multiple mechanisms, CADRO's R) Multi‑target is the appropriate choice. The negative trial outcomes and imaging findings (no delay in agitation/psychosis, higher adverse events and greater brain volume loss) do not change the mechanistic classification but support the interpretation of the trial’s clinical focus and effects. citeturn0search2turn0search1

Web evidence (selected sources supporting the above): (1) ADCS trial description and objectives confirming primary aim to delay emergence of agitation/psychosis. citeturn0search0 (2) Published trial reports and analyses showing no benefit for delaying agitation/psychosis and findings of greater brain volume loss with divalproex. citeturn0search8turn0search2 (3) Mechanistic summaries showing valproate’s multiple actions including GABAergic effects, sodium channel modulation, and HDAC (epigenetic) inhibition. citeturn0search4turn0search5
